title: global climate strike wonderful thing see new generation rise
story: Young people took to the streets of Derry over the weekend to demand action against climate change.Hundreds of Derry students left school on Friday as part of a global climate strike to sound the alarm about what is widely viewed as an “environmental emergency”.And again on Saturday, young people were at the centre of the Our Earth Our Future March, Rally and Gathering which retraced the original civil rights route from the Waterside to the Guildhall.At Friday’s climate strike, one organiser, Rois Hutton, told the crowd they must target political parties and people with influence to insist upon "radical quick changes" so that "we can ensure the survival of the human race.”Another of those behind the strike action, Emma Farren, said that this strike dfered from those held on previous occasions because adults had taken a stand alongside the youth of the city.She urged those in attendance to continue to stand with them to bring about meaningful change.Their actions prompted veteran civil rights activist, Eamonn McCann, to declare on Saturday that in all his years of campaigning he has never been more "hopeful"."What made me hopeful is the composition of the marches. The median age is under . Its a wonderful thing to see a new generation rise up and the first in my letime that % of marchers were women."I would put all my trust in the young women of Ireland to make a dference. I dont mean to be patronising but they are leaders of the future."Campaigns can rise and fall when the excitement passes but it is of the utmost importance that we stay on the same track because together we will save the climate, and world, for another generation."On Friday school pupils throughout the North of Ireland joined with millions of people around the world in staging protests.Some primary school classes, accompanied by their teachers, could be seen making their way to the city centre with placards carrying environmental messages.The iconic Free Derry Wall bore a stark message throughout the week. It read: “YOU ARE NOW ENTERING EXTINCTION ”, and encouraged people to join the environmental movement.By Saturday that message had been defaced by someone who scrawled "globalist agenda" underneath.The catalyst for the environmental movement is fteen-year-old climate activist Greta Thunberg. Last year she protested for more than a month prior to Swedens parliamentary elections by sitting alone on the steps of the parliament building in Stockholm.Following the elections she spent Fridays there demanding the government undertake a radical response to climate change.She has since inspired a mass movement supported by people, young and old, around the world.On Saturday Derry people continued to champion her cause by carrying placards reading, The Sea is Rising and so are We and We Need to Change the Politics not the Climate.Linda O Sullivan of Friends of the Earth told an audience gathered in the Guildhall that we are facing an "existential crisis" and people "need to be held accountable".And Paddy Nash, musician and environmentalist, sang a song inspired by the Save Our Sperrins campaign against gold mining. Amongst its lyrics: "Whats more precious than gold "The land, the sea, the air that we breathe, thats more precious than gold."googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: magherafelt based actor blown away role movie linked jurassic world franchise
story: By Cathal McGuiganA Magherafelt-based actor has said he was “blown away” when he learned he had been cast in Battle at Big Rock, a short film thats part of the Jurassic World franchise.Chris Finlaysonplays American biker Greg in the film and aims to build on this role and some experience as an extra to land more acting roles.Battle at Big Rock was posted to Youtube on Sunday and had been viewed more than three million times by Thursday evening. Starring alongside Chris in the film were André Hollandand Natalie Martinez .Scottish-born Chrismoved to Magherafelt in , where he worked as a personal trainer. He said that his acting career really began when the opportunity arose to work as an extra on Game of Thrones.As well as appearing as a member of the Nights Watch in three seasons of the show, hes also featured in Superman drama Krypton and filmed sword-fighting scenes for the film Viking Destiny, which is available on Netflix.He first heard about the Jurassic World role when a friend tagged him on Facebook in a post from Louise Kiely Casting, which gave away very few details about the role.“They were looking for a biker with a flawless American accent. I just thought Id go for it and see what happens,” he said.Chris said that when it came to the day of the audition in Dublin he was “sweating bullets” and almost didnt go through with it.“Just as I was walking up to the door, I sort of freaked out. I went past it and I said to myself I cant do this just because of the nerves, because I wanted it so badly,” he said.“Then I was thinking to myself, youve come this far, you need to do this. I genuinely thought I didnt stand a chance as I knew Id be up against actors with more experience.”“I went and got myself two pints of Guinness, settled my nerves and went back. I was happy when I came out and thought Id done well but I thought it would just be good experience and that I wasnt going to get it.”A few weeks later the casting agent emailed Chris to let him know that the role was his, but he still didnt know exactly what he had been cast in.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh“I thought it was probably some low-budget thing, but I was happy to get the experience and a few lines. To me, that would be a start at least.”Chris found a few clues about the production by looking up Jurassic World  director Colin Trevorrow on IMDB, but it was only at a costume fitting that he fully realised how big an opportunity he had been given.“They werent even allowed to say it but it was so secret,” he said.“One of the girls said to me that all they tell could me was that it rhymes with schminosaurs and I just knew. I was just blown away because Ive always loved Jurassic Park.”The eight-minute film was filmed in January in Co Wicklow, which means that Chris is happy to finally be able to talk about the role hes had to keep under wraps for months.“The weirdest thing is just seeing my name in the credits. Thats one of the most surreal things,” he said.Chris said that he hopes to find an agent in the near future to help him land more roles. He believes that a talent for accents hes developed from a young age can help him secure some great parts.“Accents have always been something that comes naturally to me. Even when I was only about four or five years old, I would talk to myself in the mirror and try out lots of dferent accents.”This skill came in handy when Chris played redneck biker Greg with an American accent so accurate that the production crew assumed it was his regular speaking voice.“Most of the crew on the set thought I was an American actor,” Chris said.“It wasnt until Id done my first scene and I asked someone what time it was, that they realised I wasnt an American. They couldnt believe it when I said Id just came down from Magherafelt.”

title: mayor renews call back supporting people programme frontline workers
story: The Mayor of Derry and Strabane has stressed the need for employers to “review their practices” and value the workers who are supporting some of the most vulnerable people in society.Supporting People Programme workers provide housing related support services, help people affected by domestic violence, those with addictions, families with child protection concerns, people in need of benefit advice and more.Earlier this year the local council unanimously backed a motion which recognised the work of frontline workers and called for an independent review into the programme, including terms and conditions of its workers.In a statement to the Derry News this week, Mayor, Michaela Boyle of Sinn Féin, reiterated the need to back workers: "As Mayor I would like to voice my support for those involved in the Supporting People Programme, and stress the need to protect and respect the rights of frontline workers."This is an issue that affects so many people in the Derry and Strabane area who are dealing daily with the challenges of providing a valuable support service helping some of the most vulnerable people in our society."This matter needs to be urgently addressed and I would encourage those employers involved to review their practices and fully acknowledge the value of the staff delivering these much needed specialist services."Niall McCarroll, UNISON community branch chairperson said the Supporting People Campaign presented "damning evidence" to Derry City and Strabane District Councils Health and Community Committee.It detailed the outworkings of outsourced public contracts and the growing crisis within the Department for Communities and NIHE funded Supporting People Programme - "a crisis which is impeding service delivery for vulnerable people and denying frontline workers the right to social justice."With specic reference to supported living workplaces, he said, the reality of outsourcing within the community sector is that some employers, unchallenged, choose not to value their frontline workers whilst garnishing a select few, who they deem worthy."The transfer of public services has many beneficiaries, however working class people are not included but rather excluded from benefiting from an honest days work."UNISON Community Branch activists are working hard and are committed to building a community wide culture of solidarity with regards the Supporting People Campaign and now with the direct involvement and support of the Mayor this solidarity focused campaign has become more dynamic and influential."The UNISON led Save the Foyle Haven Campaign began with the workers getting organised, the wider community mobilising in support and finally DCSDC joined the campaign through the office of the Mayor and collectively the workers driven movement protected jobs and a much valued and needed service."He continued: "These are the fundamentals of any trade union movement campaigning formula, a blueprint for equality, integrity and the downfall of self serving governance."On behalf of our branch membership a UNISON delegation will now meet with the Mayor to deliver a list of human rights based questions, for both employers and all relevant statutory bodies to provide answers."The employers and statutory agencies will now be called in front of the DCSDC Health and Community Committee to engage in the UNISON led Supporting People Campaign as we focus on protecting the Supporting People programme and safeguarding frontline workers against corporate greed and those not fit for purpose employers who operate within this sector."The right of everyone to the enjoyment of just and favourable conditions of work is recognised in the United Nations International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, its time this same right was honoured and upheld within the Supporting People programme."UNISON would like to thank the DCSDC Health and Community Committee for the genuine support offered following the UNISON presentation to council and we look forward to working closely with them in the future."googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot title: ulster university responds questions regarding city deal funds medical school
story: The Derry News posed a number of questions to Ulster Universityover the continued uncertainty on the establishment of a Medical School at Magee College.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshFirstly, we asked does UU have any update or response regarding the medical school and concerns raised by David Sterling around the need for ongoing funding which UU is not prepared to invest   A spokesperson for Ulster University commented: "Following cross-party political and health and social care support in  for Ulster University’s Graduate Entry Medical School, the University has continued to proactively develop the project, working closely with the Department and other relevant partners. Our responses to any remaining clarications within the Graduate Entry Medical School business case were submitted to the Department of Health at the start of July, following prompt and close engagement with the Department and other relevant partners. Our proposed first academic year of projected enrolments outlined within the updated business case is  .“As the Department of Health has previously confirmed that any decision on funding can only be made by Ministers, the University is not actively recruiting medical students as yet for  entry until that decision on funding can be reached.· If funding was confirmed, all other elements of the proposal for our medical undergraduate degree programme have been firmly on track including continued progress with the GMC, clinical placement opportunities and the development of a curriculum to meet the needs of healthcare locally.“We value the continued support of all those who share our vision for medical education and we continue to work with the General Medical Council, St George’s University of London and local clinicians and partners building on our existing leadership in medical and healthcare provision to take forward graduate entry medical education for Northern Ireland."What does UU say in response to local councillors representatives who have claimed that UU has neglected the Magee campus for decades and should not be given money as part of the City Deal but should instead invest its own money in Derry   A spokesperson for Ulster University commented: "Ulster University continues to invest in the Magee campus, most recently with the state-of-the-art £m teaching block which signals our ambition for higher education in the city, already enhancing campus le and paving the way for enhanced future capacity at Magee.    This and other investment priorities for students have resulted in a very strong performance for the Magee campus across all elements of the  National Student Survey, reflecting the very positive reaction from our students to these recent investments in University le at Magee.  With all four faculties of the University represented on the Magee campus – across health sciences, arts and humanities, business and computing and engineering, we are pushing boundaries and breaking new ground in emerging sectors as a progressive university, shortlisted for the prestigious Times Higher Education University of the Year Award, .“Our contribution to the City Deal opportunity is a signicant step forward in our collective opportunity to realise the full ambitions of this vibrant university city.  Our City Deals proposal will see us apply our expertise to help maximize the city’s potential in this unparalleled opportunity to boost economic growth and prosperity.  In our continued collaboration with industry partners, we look forward to driving innovation in personalised medicine, cognitive analytics, robotics and automation, leading to both new research posts and learning opportunities for additional students.  The proposed riverfront innovation hub will build upon the expertise of our first data analytics Institute, opened in  and headquartered at Magee campus, and which cemented our reputation as a global leader in this field. Also integral to the City Deal remains our commitment to establishing a Graduate Entry Medical School in a bid to address the challenges of a healthcare system at breaking point.   City Deal recognises the crucial role our University can play as an economic engine in the North West and is a major boost to the collective ambitions of the city and region.  We look forward to the development of our projects in partnership with industry, civic and educational partners."How much money will be needed in total to fund the projects put forward as part of the City Deal A spokesperson for Ulster University commented: "The funding contributions by project across City Deal and the Inclusive Futures Funds are indicative at this stage, based on the allocations provided by Council, and subject to adjustment as we go forward.  Our contribution of % University funding to the Magee projects within City Deal reflects our belief in the impact they will make, and our commitment to playing our part in the collective ambitions of City Deal.“City Deal enables us to build further on our academic strengths that are signicant for the region’s growth, and to make sure that this expertise across world class research and progressive student learning works hard for the benefit of all in the city region. The City Deal bid has education, innovation, job creation and skills development at its core and each of these priorities are also central to our work across both teaching and research.  We are therefore a natural fit and a committed partner in this ambitious bid.  A continued collaborative approach is essential as we prepare to take forward the projects through planning and design and development of the business cases.”

title: ‘Bomb component’ found during security operation
story: POLICE have confirmed that a suspected mortar component was recovered during a security operation near Castlewellan last week.The item was discovered by a member of the public on the Priests Road last Wednesday evening.Detective Inspector Graham Orr, from the PSNIrsquos Terrorism Investigation Unit, thanked the local community for their cooperation as police worked to make the scene safe.ldquoA number of cordons which had been in place have now been lted, he said.ldquoThe component will now be subject to detailed forensic examination. However, our initial assessment is that while this was not a viable device, it is clear that this is a component that could have been part of something more sinister.He added: ldquoWe know that the vast majority of people support our police officers and simply want to live in a peaceful society.ldquoWe will continue to work with communities to disrupt the activities of the small group of people who are intent on using violence.Slieve Croob Ulster Unionist councillor Alan Lewis said he was shocked by the discovery and praised ldquothe quick and efficient response of local police who sealed off the area.ldquoI commend the diligence of the local resident who spotted the device and altered emergency services, he said.Cllr Lewis called for a police investigation into republican terrorist activity in South Down.ldquoThe discovery of the mortar bomb on Thursday should concern every law abiding citizen of South Down and beyond, he said.This isn`t an isolated incident and is yet another indication of republican terrorist activity in the South Down area.ldquoI will be meeting with the PSNI next week to raise the concerns of the local community at the increased level of republican terrorist activity in South Down.ldquoI believe that there is a clear need for an increase in police patrols within the area and increased vigilance from the public. I hope that the Chief Constable will be able to ensure that local police commanders have the adequate resources made available so they can go after the terrorists.He added: ldquoThese republican criminals are attempting to hold our community to ransom and I would like to see a focused and properly resourced PSNI investigation into their activities to disrupt and take down their structures before they murder or seriously injure anyone..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch man admits selling southern Tayto in Northern Ireland
story: A BALLYNAHINCH man has admitted breaching the trademark of crisp manufacturing giant Tayto.At Belfast High Court last week, Mark Ferris admitted selling the same name brand crisps from the Republic in Northern Ireland and may be liable for damages.The sole trader claims he only made around pound profit from the sale of Tayto crisps manufactured in the Republic to shops and pubs north of the border, a judge was told.A lawyer for  year-old Ferris argued that the Northern Ireland company was ldquousing a very large sledgehammer to crack a very small nut in seeking a further hearing to examine any potential financial compensation.But counsel for the Tandragee-based firm insisted it was about protecting its trademark.According to Peter Hopkins action was only taken against Mr Ferris after he was sent four letters warning him to stop selling the southern brand.ldquoOne misconception is the impression given, to put it colloquially, that he was some innocent abroad, the barrister said. ldquoIt was a breach of the law, and two separate companies trading north and south.Tayto Northern Ireland issued trademark infringement proceedings against Mr Ferris, trading as Candy Plus, with the case relating to his alleged sale of Tayto crisps from the Republic at locations in Belfast and where.Mr Justice Huddleston was told Mr Ferris has operated a business from his home over the past three years, selling confectionery, snacks and drinks.His barrister, Kevin Morgan, confirmed that the breach was admitted, but stressed that no counterfeit goods were involved.ldquoThe southern Tayto were legally purchased by him in the Republic of Ireland, counsel maintained.Questioning why action was taken against his client, Mr Morgan argued that the same crisps are being sold throughout Northern Ireland.He described Mr Ferrisrsquo business as ldquominuscule when compared to Tayto Northern Ireland ldquoIn the last year he estimates that he earned pound, in profits. By comparison, the plaintf has been estimated in the recent past to have a turnover of poundm and is the third largest snack manufacturer in the UK, the lawyer said.Mr Morgan claimed that a public judgment against the defendant would be more valuable to the crisps company than a prolonged investigation into what profits Candy Plus made from selling Irish Tayto.He also disclosed that his client was willing to make a pound payment as part of any settlement.However, the court heard it was being wrongly portrayed as a ldquoDavid and Goliath case.Mr Hopkins challenged the lack of evidence to back assertions Mr Ferris only made pound profit from the trademark infringement.Entering judgment for Tayto Northern Ireland, Mr Justice Huddleston said: ldquoI fully accept this case is not at the higher end of the scale of either culpability or breach, but nonetheless itrsquos a breach and for that consequences do follow.Awarding costs to the company and remitting the case to a High Court master for further financial examinations, Mr Justice Huddleston added: ldquoUntil therersquos an assessment of damages or an account of profits we are at a loss..prettyPhoto

title: Doors to close at primary school
story: THE death knell has been sounded for Castlewellan Primary School.The beleaguered school, which currently has only eight pupils, will close by the end of August next year at the earliest.The Education Authority yesterday sent out letters announcing that it had approved a proposal to close the school along with its Moderate Learning Dficulty class.There will now be a two-month period for objectors to make their views known, after which a final decision will be taken.School principal Niall McLean said yesterday: ldquoIt is highly regrettable that it has come to this, but we have to face reality.The school, which has been in existence for  years, has been experiencing falling enrolment numbers for several years.The school has capacity for  pupils and of the eight children currently on the register, six are in the Moderate Learning Dficulty class and two in the P-P class. In ,  children attended the school.The writing on the wall came when a proposed merger with nearby Annsborough Integrated Primary School to create a controlled integrated school was abandoned in the face of falling pupil numbers.In May the Education Authority issued a document in which it stated that Castlewellan Primary would close and Annsborough Integrated would be retained.The document said numbers at Castlewellan Primary had declined ldquoto a point where the potential establishment of a controlled integrated primary school was no longer viable.The closure will mark the end of controlled education in the town. Castlewellan High School closed in  when it merged with Killyleagh and Quoile high schools to form Down Academy mdash now Blackwater integrated College mdash in Downpatrick.Mr McLean said staff would continue to give pupils ldquothe best possible education until the school closes its doors for the final time.ldquoI have been here for  years. It is disheartening when you put your heart into your job mdash as every teacher does mdash only for your school to be taken away, he remarked.ldquoWe are still a happy school, but it will be a very sad day for the school, the children, the staff, the parents and the community when it closes.All objections to the closure proposal should be made to the Department of Education, Rathgael House, Balloo Road, Bangor..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick mum hosts charity singing competition in aid of ALPS
story: THE mother of a Downpatrick man who sought help from a local mental health organisation during a low point in his le is hosting a local version of The Voice singing competition, starting this Saturday night.Joanne Flynn says she is organising a series of three heats and a grand final of the popular reality TV show at Fitzpatrickrsquos Bar in Church Street in aid of All Lives Are Precious .Joanne describes being amazed at the support her  year-old son, Michael, received from the non-profit community organisation when he was battling a bout of depression a few years ago.ALPS, which relies heavily on goodwill from volunteers and members of the public for its survival, offers support and services on emotional well-being, mental health education and suicide prevention.Joanne said: ldquoI am so grateful to ALPS. They acted fast and got him the help he needed.ldquoWe know too well that men in particular find it hard to talk about this kind of thing. Irsquom just glad my son did. I can never thank Ronan Gilchrist and the ALPS team enough. They are really a fantastic organisation.ldquoEven though Michael still battles with depression the counselling he got was effective. It helped him so much and we will always be very thankful to them.Joanne added: ldquoI want to thank all the local businesses who have donated to our raffle and to everyone who has contributed with their time and effort to help make each night a success.ldquoThe evenings also offer an opportunity for unsung local talent to shine. Although the four evenings are free admission there will be a pound donation payable at the door.ldquoIf we make over pound, we will be very happy with our efforts. It is advised to come along early to ensure you get a good seat.The Voice ndash Downpatrick starts at pm this Saturday and will run over four Saturdays, with the grand final taking place on October . Anyone over  can still take part..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum broadband upgrade work begins
story: WORK has started on the roll-out of a new full fibre broadband network in Dundrum as part of an poundm investment.Fibrus mdash Northern Irelandrsquos full fibre broadband provider mdash is carrying out the work in the village and has plans to provide the new service in many other parts of the Province over the coming months, bringing state of the art technology to homes and businesses via a quality broadband service.To launch the new connection, Fibrus was recently joined by Dundrumrsquos most famous son Patrick Kielty at an event in the village which will see a new, fast broadband service for homes and businesses in the local area.Fibrus chairman Conal Henry said the company was delighted to finally get underway with the roll out and could not wait to bring the digital infrastructure to Northern Ireland that is fit for purpose and future proof for the next  to  years.ldquoResilient and fast full fibre connectivity is the corner stone of the most advanced societies and we will invest heavily in connecting homes and businesses throughout Northern Ireland, he continued.ldquoThe Fibrus team has been working hard to get ready for this build and we continue to strengthen our team with the expertise to build a state-of-the-art network at pace.ldquoWe are also delighted to announce the appointment of Conor Harrison as our chief operating officer who brings over  yearsrsquo experience building telecoms networks.He added: ldquoOur initial investment in full fibre broadband is poundm and we have exciting plans to increase the roll out of this innovative and transformative technology across Northern Ireland.ldquoThe UK Government has set out its ambitious plans for swapping out the legacy copper with new fibre infrastructure and Fibrus plans to play a central role in reaching ubiquitous fibre coverage in Northern Ireland by ..prettyPhoto

title: Firms toast generosity of Crossgar community
story: A CROSSGAR business has presented two local kidney patient support charities with pound, each following a series of fundraising events.Mageersquos Bar  Wine Lodge has also been supporting Sandra Robinson mdash who is originally from the village and is undertaking a tandem skye in memory of her late husband Jimbo who was a long-term kidney dialysis patient.For her fundraiser, Sandra is supporting Kidney Care UK and the NI Kidney Patientrsquos Association .Roger Magee, proprietor of Mageersquos Bar and Wine Lodge, has thanked everyone who contributed to the massive fundraising effort.ldquoAs a kidney dialysis patient at the renal unit at Belfast City Hospital for almost three years, I know only too well what it means to receive the reassurance of support and assistance, he explained.ldquoFrom our terric snail race evening which saw the bar and lounge jam-packed with supporters to our many fundraising efforts, we were delighted to get behind Sandra Robinson. She is a very special lady indeed and to literally take to the skies to help support patients is truly remarkable.Roger explained that local kidney patients will benefit in so many dferent ways from the terric awareness raising which has been achieved around Sandrarsquos skye.ldquoWe were delighted to be part of it, continued Roger. ldquoThe public are always so generous but we need people to think more about becoming an organ donor and having that vital family conversation.ldquoOn behalf of my we Joan and everyone at Mageersquos Bar  Wine Lodge I want to thank everyone who helped us to raise such a terric sum for these two super charities.Thanking Roger and Joan, Jo-Anne Dobson, kidney donor and NI Ambassador for Kidney Care UK, said the organisation had so much fun supporting Sandra in what has become a personal crusade to raise awareness of organ donation and to help patients.She continued: ldquoRoger, Joan and everyone at Mageersquos have been a terric support and I thank them all from the bottom of my heart. This amazing financial contribution will enable both charities to continue the vital work of helping to support local kidney.ldquoFrom Belfast to Crossgar and right up to Garvagh, Sandra has been talking transplants and promoting a beautul story of love in memory of her late husband Jimbo it truly is a leap of love.Mrs Dobson said that at Kidney Care UK, a leading patient support charity, everyone believes that no one should be left to fight kidney disease alone.She added: ldquoThatrsquos why we provide dedicated practical, financial and emotional support for patients across the seven local renal units in Northern Ireland.Kidney recipient William Johnston, patient advocacy officer for Kidney Care UK and co-chair of NIKPA, said the charity was ldquoextremely grateful to Roger and Joan for their amazing fundraising and for the support which they are providing to Sandrarsquos skye which has certainly captured the public imagination.He added: ldquoThe promotion of the organ donation message is central to ensuring that everyone who needs a transplant has a better chance of receiving one. Through our work we want to make people think about becoming a donor and also crucially to tell their loved ones their wishes.ldquoMassive thanks to Roger, Joan, Sandra and everyone involved for all they are doing to support our ongoing services for kidney patients and their families..prettyPhoto

title: Fond farewells at Downpatrick School of Lifesaving
story: DOWNPATRICK School of Lesaving has said goodbye to two of its stalwarts.It was an emotional occasion when presentations were made to Yvonne Smyth and Rachel Kelly, who have bade farewell.Yvonne has been a member of Downpatrick School of Lesaving for  years mdash the last  of them as a coach.During that time, Yvonne has been at the forefront of organising additional training for all our senior and junior coaches, especially in regards to disability and autism training.Her dedication to inclusion training was also recognised when she received the SANDSADisability Coach of the Year Award.A spokesman said: ldquoYvonne has been a huge asset to the club not only as a lesaving and swimming teacher, but in her administration role within the club.ldquoShe maintained the qualication and Access NI records of the coaches, ensuring all paperwork was correct. Allied to this she registered the junior coaches with Volunteer Now. This ensured their service to DSL was recognised and certied.ldquoHer focus was the personal development of the young members of DSL from their initiation to lesaving at six years of age until leaving for university or work with an impressive CV.Rachel, one of the parent helpers, has been with Downpatrick School of Lesaving for several years. In that time she has assisted with the administration, training of young coaches in relation to working with people with a disability and assisting parent helpers in their role with the club.The spokesman added: ldquoIt is with a heavy heart that we at DSL say farewell to both ladies. We offer Yvonne and Rachel and their family our best wishes and hope that they may be able toat some time in the future..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C September 25%2C 1979
story: NEWCASTLE mdash A decline in hotel and guest house accommodation in Newcastle over the past seven years has been offset by a staggering rise of more than poundm in revenue from daytrippers, who have just voted the Co Down resort the best in Ireland.That was the mixed news for the future of the townrsquos tourist industry with the publication this week of a Northern Ireland Tourist Board survey, the first of its kind since .Newcastle was compared in the survey to two other resorts mdash Portrush and Bangor mdash and not only did it outstrip its rivals in the daytrippersrsquo stakes but it was the only resort to actually increase its revenue since .While Portrush and Bangorrsquos earnings fell, Newcastle increased its income by more than  per cent.A detailed breakdown of the figures shows that , day-trippers visited the town last year, a dramatic rise of , on the  figure.The income from daytrippers has also swollen considerably, to over poundm, although when this figure is deflated to rsquo price levels, last yearrsquos total revenue is almost halved.This growth is in direct opposition to the trend at Bangor, where one-day visitors ped by more than  per cent, and at Portrush where the revenue in real terms dropped by over pound,.The report stresses that ldquothis growth reflects the efforts made by Newcastle Town Committee and Down District Council to provide a series of special events in the resort.The results of the survey have been welcomed by the Councilrsquos recreation and tourist officer, Mr Bryan Coburn.ldquoI am delighted with these figures, this is a big boost for the work which the council has been carrying on in Newcastle, he said.POPE VISIT mdash The South Eastern Education and Library Board has refused to be drawn on the one-day closure of local schools next Monday for the Popersquos visit.Board members were asked this week to support a call that all schools should be offered an alternative date rather than have what has been termed ldquoan exceptional holiday.At a meeting on Tuesday the career teachersrsquo union, NAS UWT, called on the Board to urge Lord Elton to allow schools, which found it dficult to close on October , to taken an alternative holiday.But after a -minute debate, during which several Board members had put forward proposals in support of NAS UWT, members agreed not to vote but to simply note the unionrsquos comments.The unionrsquos letter said that Lord Eltonrsquos circular about taking next Monday off placed many inidual controlled schools in a dficult position. Several of them would be subjected to severe political pressurethey made a decision to close on Monday.At the outset of the discussion the boardrsquos chairman, Mr Cecil Kirkwood, said he did not wish to open debate on the already widely discussed issue. The allocation of exceptional holidays remained a matter of departmental policy whatever board members might think inidually.Mrs Ethel Smyth said the matter was causing great concern in the area and that she had already condemned Lord Elton for the action he had taken in offering Monday as an exceptional holiday.Only a native lord from England would have made such a mistake. In her view, it might have been quite proper for the Roman Catholic maintained schools take one of their ten optional days holidays to see their spiritual leader of their church.In all but one of the controlled schools in her area good sense had prevailed and those schools would remain open on Monday. She thought closure of a controlled school had bogus and dishonest characteristics.KNOCK MASS mdash A former Downpatrick man who was ordained a priest only three years ago, at the age of , will take part in the concelebrated Mass attended by the Pope at Knock this weekend.The Rev John McCusker mdash who will be  next month mdash only seriously thought of the priesthood after the death of his we, and he began his studies in Wales in .Father McCusker, father of Mrs T Connor, of  Struel Road, Downpatrick, was ordained by Bishop Casey, of Walsh in  and is at present centred in the Lady Fatima Home, Tralee, County Kerry.Before his call to the priesthood, Father McCusker was manager of the Falls Road branch of the Northern Bank.DOWNPATRICK mdash Down Hockey Clubrsquos new pound, ground at Strangford Road mdash reckoned to be good enough to house international games mdash was officially opened on Friday by Mr Dixon Rose, president of the Ulster Hockey branch.Mr Rose, who stressed the possibility of bringing international hockey to the County town couldnrsquot be ruled out now such top-class facilities were available, officially opened the ground before the big challenge game between the Presidentrsquos XI and a specially strengthened Down XI, which included three internationals.The big crowd attended the openingand heard club president Mr Jim McClurg pay tribute to those who made the ground possible.Mr McClurg said that it was a great achievement that the club, not so long after celebrating its th anniversary, took the necessary steps to ensure a top class ground. And this had worked out well, with the official opening this year mdash the year the club step back into senior ranks for the first time in  years.A challenge game took place with Downrsquos strengthened XI drawing - with the Ulster Presidentrsquos XI.Down fielded with internationals Harry Burns, Stewart McAnulty and Philip Anderson and gave as good as they got in the first half. Play fluctuated but although several half chances were created, none were created, none were created and so the interval came with no score on the board.Down took the lead in the second half when Geoffrey Ferguson scored from a penalty corner but just when it looked like Down would emerge winners, the Presidentrsquos XI equalised from a well taken penalty flick by S Martin.SAINTFIELD mdash Former schoolteacher John Anderson, from Saintfield, has established himself as the most prominent music maker in the province since leaving his teaching profession.He compiles and produces a Radio Ulster programme of serious music every Saturday and has arranged all the music for the successful musical at the Arts Theatre last year.John has grown up with the music mdash his father plays the organ and his mother is a well known singer mdash and it was no surprise when he wrote the lyrics and music for lsquoAll the Kings Horsesrsquo.Despite his success John Anderson, who taught at Methodist College, admits that he misses teaching, as it can be lsquoenormously rewardingrsquo.DOWNPATRICK mdash Four workmen were injured in a gas explosion at the Downshire Hospital early on Monday morning.The men, who were working on vents to the hospitalrsquos kitchen, were in a site storage hut when the explosion happened.The were taken to the intensive care unit of the nearby Down Hospital with blast burns to their hands and faces and their condition were later described as ldquocomfortable.ROAD RUN mdash Downe Olde Car Club held their Bill Patterson Memorial run on Saturday with more than  cars taking part.The run, in memory of the man who first thought of forming such a club in the area, started in Downpatrick and continued through Ballynahinch, Seaforde, Clough, Balykinlar, Tyrella, Killough, Ardglass, Kilclief, Strangford, Killyleagh, Ballooo Ballygowan, Saintfield and finished at Crossgar.Only one stop was made throughout the journey, at Kilclief, where the ious drivers had a picnic..prettyPhoto

title: Irish broadcaster to show No Stone Unturned documentary
story: RTEacute is to screen the controversial documentary No Stone Unturned detailing the circumstances behind the  Loughinisland massacre.The network has become the first public service broadcaster to commit to screening the feature- documentary which chronicles the deaths of six innocent Catholic men shot dead by UVF gunmen at the Heights Bar.The men were watching Ireland play Italy in a World Cup football match when gunmen burst into the pub with assault rles and fired on the customers. In addition to killing six men, five others were wounded.The documentary is being screened on RTE  next Wednesday, October , at .pm.Through interviews with the victimsrsquo families, former terrorists, RUC officers and other government officials, Alex Gibneyrsquos film explores the incongruities of the case and alleged collusion between police and paramilitary forces.Belfast journalists Trevor Birney and Barry McCaffrey were arrested following the making of the film over the alleged theft of a Police Ombudsman for Northern Ireland document, with the charges ultimately being ped.This followed a court ruling that search warrants issued against the journalists had been ldquoinappropriate when police seized a wide range of material during early morning raids on their homes and at their film company.The case attracted worldwide attention, with the award-winning reporters having mobilised a high-profile campaign against what was perceived as an attack on press freedom.Mr Birney has described RTErsquos decision to screen the documentary as a ldquovery signicant moment for this film.He continued: ldquoIt is signicant not just for everyone involved in the production, but for the families of those murdered in the Loughinisland massacre, who have campaigned for truth for over  years.ldquoWe thank everyone at RTEacute who have shown faith in our journalism.RTEacutersquos managing editor of current affairs, David Nally, said the broadcaster was delighted to be screening the powerful documentary.He added: ldquoJournalism that helps unearth the hidden stories behind the Northern Ireland troubles is a very important public service. These stories can be uncomfortable but in the end, truth matters.Sinn Fein MLA Emma Rogan, whose father, Adrian, was one of the six men gunned down in the Loughinisland pub, has praised RTEacutersquos decision to screen the documentary.She said: ldquoThe Loughinisland families are delighted that the national broadcaster is to screen No Stone Unturned. This is justication for filmmakers Trevor Birney and Barry McCaffrey who were arrested for telling our truth.ldquoThe decision to screen the documentary is also a vindication for former Police Ombudsman Dr Michael Maguire..prettyPhoto

title: Late Laverty goal seals Kilcoo win
story: KILCOOrsquoS epitaph was being written as the remnants of hurricane Humberto swept into Pairc Esler on Saturday night.But there was an even bigger storm happening down on the pitch.Kilcoo trailed - to - with five minutes of this thrilling encounter remaining as the rain pelted down.Things didnrsquot look good for them. They hadnrsquot played well all night, but suddenly everything clicked and a Paul Devlin penalty and an instinctive finish from Conor Laverty turned this game on its head as Kilcoo scored - to Burrenrsquos - in the dying stages to book their semi-final spot against Clonduff mdash Warrenpoint will play Ballyholland in the other semi-final.Spare a thought for the Frank OrsquoHare Cup holders.They had got their tactics spot on and nullied Kilcoorsquos attacking threat for most of the game, but never ever write Kilcoo off.Donal OrsquoHare and Eugene Branagan swapped early scores before Paul Devlin converted a free to send Kilcoo into a seventh minute lead. However, a composed Burren retaliated in style and a patient period of possession saw Paddy OrsquoRourkersquos side jump into a - to - lead thanks to a goal from Connor Toner.Kilcoo chipped away at the lead and despite firing over a few wides, points from Devlin and Laverty had it all square by the th minute, - to -.Frees from OrsquoHare and lsquokeeper Cathal Murdock edged Burren back in front, but Laverty ensured Kilcoo stayed in touch with a point from play. OrsquoHare and Jerome Johnston exchanged points before OrsquoHare was perfectly placed to net hi sidersquos second goal and give his side a clear - tom- lead after  minutes.Liam Kerr stretched that lead out to five points as the half drew to close, but Paul Devlin gave Kilcoo renewed hope when he left four points between the sides at the break, - to -.Kerr and Ryan McEvoy swapped points at the start of the second half before points from Laverty and Ryan Johnston left two points in it with  minutes remaining.OrsquoHare and Ryan Treanor made it a four-point game with five minutes remaining, but when the going gets tough, the tough get going.A Paul Devlin point was followed by a penalty from the same player after Anthony Morgan had been fouled.Kilcoo were now level, but within  seconds they had somehow taken a - to - lead with added time approaching fast.A Padraig Poland point left two it, but Paul Devlin had the last say when he lofted over the final score of the game and complete a remarkable comeback.Kilcoo: Martin McCourt, Niall Branagan, Aiden Branagan, Niall McEvoy, Aaron Branagan, Darryl Branagan, Miceal Rooney, James McClean, Ryan McEvoy , Dylan Ward, Paul Devlin , Eugene Branagan , Aaron Morgan, Jerome Johnston , Conor Laverty . Subs: Ryan Johnstonfor Aaron Morgan, Shealan Johnston for Eugene Branagan, Anthony Morgan for Niall McEvoy, Marty Devlin for Ryan McEvoy, Sean OrsquoHanlon for Dylan Ward.Burren: Cathal Murdock , Peter Fegan, Kevin McKernan, Malachi McAvoy, Eamonn Toner, Conail McGovern, Conor Cox, Mark McKay, Ryan Treanor, Cathal Foy, Connor Toner , Eamonn Toner, Donal OrsquoHare , Liam Kerr , Declan Rooney. Subs: Ronan McGrath for Foy , Padraig Polandfor Eamonn Toner, Ryan Cunningham for McKay, Ardan McAvoy for Fegan..prettyPhoto

title: Local Ulster in Bloom success
story: A NUMBER of local towns featured prominently in this yearrsquos Ulster in Bloom competition.Newcastle finished third in the small town category, while Quinnrsquos Bar in the resort picked up a special award for outstanding floral presentation at its Central Promenade.And Saintfield also scooped a special award for its impressive judgesrsquo pack showcasing all of the townrsquos Ulster in Bloom efforts.The results of the prestigious competition sponsored by Translink were public last week, with the ious local winners delighted they were recognised among Northern Irelandrsquos top horticultural talent.Ulster in Bloom encourages cities, towns and villages across the Province to look their best, boosting civic pride through beautul plant and floral displays.Translink board member Dr Mark Sweeney congratulated all the winners and those who took part in the competition.He said that collectively they had ldquocreated the most stunning plant and floral displays showcasing their areas and making Northern Ireland a more attractive place to live, visit and work.Dr Sweeney added: ldquoThanks to all the local councils, businesses, community groups and Translink employees who have worked so hard to improve their local area and make such a positive lasting impression on both local people and visitors.ldquoLike Ulster in Bloom, Translink is committed to environmental care and we have been busy transforming public transport to support the growth and prosperity of villages, towns and cities.Cllr Frances Burton, president of the Northern Ireland Local Government Association mdash the umbrella body for all  district councils mdash also thanked those who supported the competition.She said championing the lsquoin bloomrsquo message of councils, local committees, residents and businesses, taking pride in the places where people live and work, creates a better environment for everyone to share..prettyPhoto

title: Mahon clinches open win
story: CROSSGAR Golf Club played host to the last competitive open of the season this weekend in the form of the joint-captainsrsquo charity event.A large field had assembled and despite an early strong wind the scoring was good from the outset.The first fourball saw two players ing  points, Mark Casement having a hole in one and the second Adrian Bell taking the clubhouse lead courtesy of  points on the back nine.It wasnrsquot long, though, before a new leader emerged with eight handicapper John Curlett playing his best round of the season.Then came something not even he could have expected when veteran Pat Mahon turned back the years with a vintage performance and a fabulous score of  points to seal his first victory in a few seasons.The gross took its usual passage to Davy Watson whilst Jimmy Keenan won the committee prize. Longest drive was won by club captain Les Watson with Adrian Bell and Gary Kennedy winning the nearest the pins.The ladiesrsquo competition saw some of the best scoring of the season with Joyce Dodd unlucky having to settle for second place with a superb  points.Maeve Fay has continued to go from strength to strength over the last few seasons and her victory with a tremendous  points just emphasises the strides she has made.Nuala Hynds and Oriel Nesbitt won the front and back nine prizes respectively with Joan Dickson winning the longest drive and Fay adding the nearest the pin to her winnersrsquo trophy.Chest Heart and Stroke was the nominated charity and just short of pound was raised..prettyPhoto

title: Malachy’s tireless work recognised by charity
story: THE Meningitis Research Foundation has thanked Downpatrick man Malachy Doran for two decades of tireless volunteering on behalf of the charity.Mr Doran recently organised his last street collection on behalf of the charity in his home town which raised pound,.Now in his eighties, Malachy and his dedicated group of volunteers took to the streets to raise much-needed funds to help defeat the disease, fund new research, campaign for new vaccines, better treatment and aftercare, and greater awareness and support.Paula Donaghy mdash the charityrsquos fundraising and support officer mdash has thanked Malachy, his family and all his collectors for their commitment and dedication.She said the Meningitis Research Foundation relied on the generosity and support of the local community to sustain its vital work.ldquoMalachy was the driving force behind the fundraising for the Foundation in the Downpatrick area and he will be greatly missed. His dedication was second to none and we will be forever grateful for his commitment and generosity of spirit.Meningitis is a cause particularly close to Malachyrsquos heart as it affected his grandson Conor when he was a baby. It was an extremely distressing time for the family, as meningitis is a deadly and very fast acting disease and Conor was critically ill.Thankfully, Conor made a complete recovery but the family were all too aware that not every one is as lucky as they were and dedicated their time to raising money and awareness for the charity.To date well over pound, has been raised from the Downpatrick area, due to the work of Malachy and his family.In fact, such has been Malachyrsquos dedication that in March he was presented with the Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairmanrsquos award for community and voluntary work for his outstanding fundraising in aid of Meningitis Research Foundation.Paula added: ldquoMalachy is an amazing man who has worked quietly and tirelessly raising funds for MRF for over  years. He has made such a huge contribution to our organisation over the years and he thoroughly deserves all the recognition he has received.Anyone interested in carrying on the great work of Malachy Doran is asked to contact the Foundationrsquos Belfast office, telephone on    or email belfast@meningitis.org..prettyPhoto

title: New programme at Lecale Gaelic Society
story: CUMANN Gaelach Leath Chathail mdash or Lecale Gaelic Society mdash have released a new extensive programme for all ages which will run along with the school calendar year.The Irish language organisation are aiming to bring the language to everyone regardless of age or current knowledge of the language.Starting at the very youngest in the community, Peek-a-Boo Suacutegradh is a parent and toddler group which runs on Wednesday mornings, -am, in the St Michaelrsquos Centre,  Irish Street, Downpatrick.This session is perfect for parents to come along with their children and introduce them to the language in a relaxed, fun and social environment, meeting other parents who wish to give their children the gt of the language as well as allowing the children to build friendships from a young age. This group is suitable for total beginners right through to fluent speakers.The naiacutescoil, or nursery school, caters for two age groups, pre-school and pre-pre-school, accepting children from  years and  months. After this children move on to the Bunscoil unit in Our Ladyrsquos and St Patrickrsquos Primary School where they learn all their subjects through the medium of Irish.After this, children have the choice of continuing on their Irish medium education in either Ardscoil Naomh Mhaolmhaodhoacutegor Colaacuteiste Feirste.Nowthat isnrsquot enough going on, the Irish language organisation has adults catered for as well, with weekly Irish language classes for beginners, intermediate and advanced level taking place on Monday nights .-.pm in the St Michaelrsquos Centre.It also hosts monthly social events to bring the community together and help welcome beginners to the language in an enjoyable environment. Events can range from wine and cheese nights, to talks and pop-up Gaeltachts.On top of all that there even is a Cumann Reathawhich meet together once a month at Castlewellanrsquos ParkRun on the second Saturday of each month.Cumann Gaelach Leath Chathail are always on the look-out for new and creative ways to help the language grow and develop within the Lecale area and beyond.If you have any ideas or would like further information on any of the events detailed above feel free to get in touch with Caitliacuten Niacute Chearuacutellaacutein at eolas@leathchathail.ie..prettyPhoto

title: Public to hear future plans for Delamont Country Park
story: PLANS for the future development of Delamont Country Park on the shores of Strangford Lough are due to made public early next month.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is preparing to unveil a blueprint for the future of the popular visitor attraction exactly one year after people were asked for their views on what they would like to see provided.The local authority is keen to make one of the best county parks of its kind in Northern Ireland even better.Last October, people were invited to put forward their views on how the stunning location outside Killyleagh could be developed to attract even more visitors.The -acre country park already attracts tens of thousands of visitors every year with a number of local politicians and those who use it on a regular basis consistently arguing that it has the capacity to do much more.Council officials say they are committed to enhancing what the country park has to offer to help attract even more visitors to what is one of the districtrsquos most popular tourist facilities and a base for a number of high profile events, including the annual Skfies Festival.Some of the ideas that emerged during the workshop included a pitch and putt course, bowling green, water sports facility, dedicated camping site and disc golf. Other suggestions included utilising part of the walled garden for public use, in particular, outdoor concerts.As council officials prepare to unveil the blueprint for the future of the country park, work is continuing to overhaul and extend the Education Authorityrsquos base in the grounds of the country park which is used to deliver a iety of outdoor courses.Several years ago, the building was earmarked for closure by education chiefs as part of a rationalisation of outdoor youth provision. But it secured a reprieve as a result of pressure from local politicians, including Rowallane councillors Billy Walker and Terry Andrews.Contractors are currently hard at work restoring and extending the facility which commands spectacular views over the country park from the front of the building and Strangford Lough from the rear.Cllr Walker, who for many years has been campaigning for more investment in the country park to provide an enhanced range of attractions for visitors, said many people were looking forward to seeing the councilrsquos future vision for Delamont.He said the country park was one of the best of its kind in the province and offered ldquounlimited development potential.Cllr Walker continued: ldquoIt is important that when the vision for the future is unveiled that local people are given an opportunity to study the document and provide comment on it.ldquoThe Education Authority stuck to its promise to invest in Delamont and it is important that the local council presses ahead with its own investment plan to make Delamont even better, capitalising on its huge development potential.Delamont currently operates a hugely successful miniature railway, cafe, stunning walks and childrenrsquos adventure playground, but Cllr Walker believes so much more can be done.He added: ldquoWhile I am not advocating that the beauty of the area is spoiled in any way, there are hundreds of acres of space which could be used to boost the parkrsquos tourism offering.ldquoSecuring finance to enhance the country park is critical to its future development and I hope others funders will join with the council on this issue..prettyPhoto

title: Resurfacing work set to start in Irish Street
story: WORK to resurface Irish Street in Downpatrick following the completion of a pound, public realm scheme is expected to start imminently.Roads officials have indicated that concerns about the state of a derelict building close to the townrsquos former police base have been addressed, paving the way for resurfacing work to start.It was revealed last month that the project had been delayed due to issues over insurance and that the work could not take place until these are resolved.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran says he has been told by roads officials that concerns about the derelict building have been ironed out and that resurfacing work will begin.Work on the regeneration project was due to be completed by March, but it was the end of June before contractors finally moved off site, with traders in the area expressing anger about the impact the delayed scheme was having on business.The delay also had a knock-on effect on traffic congestion in other parts of the town as a result of the temporary one-way traffic system in Irish Street.Managed by the Departments for Infrastructure and Communities and Newry Mourne and Down Council, the scheme has resulted in new granite paving, street lighting and street furniture.The delay in completing the public realm work within the anticipated three-month timeframe was blamed on a number of factors, described as ldquounforeseen works issues, that resulted in the loss of construction time and delays in delivering the scheme.Issues which arose included the identication of asbestos piping along both sides of Irish Street which resulted in the works contract being put on hold for eight weeks. In addition, the foundations of the old blast wall at the former PSNI base posed construction issues for contractors.Cllr Curran said that while the Irish Street scheme was ldquobeset by problems and delays it was important to look forward.ldquoA lot of water has passed under the bridge since a one-way traffic system was introduced in Irish Street at the start of the year. While a number of factors delayed the project, it is important that work on the resurfacing scheme is now completed, he continued.ldquoIrish Street offers so much potential, both for the businesses located there and people who live at this very historic part of the town. The street has been transformed as a result of signicant investment which was long overdue.Cllr Curran said a new group was formed in July to oversee a pound, scheme to help revitalise shop fronts at Irish Street, with the so-called lsquorevitalisation fundingrsquo provided by the Department for Communities and local authority to help business owners improve the fronts of their respective properties.A working group to steer the project forward has been formed, with traders encouraged to come up with schemes to improve shop fronts.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThis is a timely initiative given what the Irish Street traders had to endure for the first six months of the year. It is also important that whatever schemes come forward that the character of this part of the town is retained.ldquoThere are also plans for an ambitious multi-million pound regeneration initiative via the redevelopment of the townrsquos former police base and a number of adjacent empty buildings. This means that the spotlight will be on Irish Street for the foreseeable future.As part of the planned commercial development, the townrsquos former police base, which enjoys protected status, could be utilised as an attractive entrance feature.Local council officials say they are excited at the development potential the Irish Street site offers and want to maximise its development opportunity..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield’s recent run ended by Rosemount
story: SAINTFIELD United ed to Pigeon Hill on Saturday looking to make it three league wins in a row, but it wasnrsquot to be as Rosemount Rec where eventually able to leave with the spoils.The Saints started the game brightly and in the opening minutes created a few opportunities, but against the run of play Rosemount took the lead when their number nine cut in from the left and found the bottom corner.From then on, Rosemount started to dominate possession and they found a second when a long-range effort found the bottom corner. Rosemount seemed to have wrapped up the game when they netted a third goal just before the break.The Saints came out flying in the second half and from the get go took the game to Rosemount.When James Sofley was brought down in the box, brother Ryan was able to step up from the spot to give Saintfield a leline.Saintfield kept the pressure on when they found a second goal from a Ryan Sofley corner which found David Morrow at the back post, and he made no mistake in heading into the top corner.Saintfield where now pushing for the equaliser, but against the run of play Rosemount were awarded a penalty which they dispatched to keep a two-goal cushion.Straight from the restart, James Sofley was sent through one on one and he found the bottom corner to make it a nervy finish, but Rosemount were able to hang on..prettyPhoto

title: Showdown time in championships
story: ITrsquoS championship semi-final showdown time this weekend with places in the SFC and IFC deciders up for grabs.The action gets underway this Friday night when giant-killing Ballyholland face Warrenpoint at Pairc Esler in the first of the Morgan Fuels SFC games.All roads then lead to St Patrickrsquos Park, Newcastle, on Saturday afternoon for both Parador Lodge IFC semi-finals between Darragh Cross and Shamrocks and Glenn and St Johnrsquos.There will be time for supporters to leave Newcastle after the second game and head to Newry for the Kilcoo v Clonduff derby at pm in the SFC.The Darragh Cross v Newry Shamrocks game opens the IFC proceedings on Saturday afternoon in Newcastle.Darragh, who are lying fourth in Division , are expected to win this clash with their Division  opponents, but they will not be taking their opponents lightly.The St Mochairsquos men have beaten Drumgath, Drumaness and Saul on the way to the semi-finals and they havenrsquot really been tested yet, although Saul did have their chances of causing an upset.With former Down U- captain Oisin McConvey back from the US, Darragh have a solid backbone to their team and Matty Hardy, Shane Murray, Michael Monan, Anton McGrattan, Joe McKinney and Marcus Miskelly are all experienced campaigners.Shamrocks have been playing well in recent weeks and have reserved their best form for the championship. Wins over Tullylish, Teconnaught and Ballymartin has propelled them into the last four.The only blot on their landscape was a defeat to Ballymartin, but they avenged that loss later in the competition. However, they have not faced any side as good as Darragh yet and Jody McGovern, Jack Haughey, Niall Rafferty, Conor Donnelly and Kevin Hegarty will have to be at their best and then somethey are to get the better of Darragh.Glenn, seen as many punditsrsquo favourites to win the competition, then take on St Johnrsquos in what promises to be another close encounter.Glenn may not have made the impact on Division  as they would have liked, but they have been impressive in championship outings against Liatroimand Saul, winning all three games in style.St Johnrsquos have been as equally impressive and wins over Annaclone, Drumgath and Teconnaught have taken them to the brink of a final.The Johnnies will again rely on the firepower of John Clarke, Marty Keenan, Danny and Chris McKay and Conor Morgan to get them over the line, but they must beware the attacking abilities of Mattie Bagnall, Denis Murtagh, Jarlath McConaghy, Jack McCartan and Patrick Brooks.The top clash of the weekend at Pairc Esler on Saturday night then takes centre stage with Clonduff out to ruinrsquos Kilcoorsquos double bid.Kilcoo, who are sitting pretty at the top of Division , look certain to regain their ACFL crown, but nothing less than winning the Frank OrsquoHare Cup will do a hungry Magpies camp.However, you have to admire Kilcoorsquos resilience and fortitude. The Branagan brothers just never know when they are beaten and when you have Conor Laverty buzzing on the edge of the square, anything can happen.Clonduffrsquos first priority will be to try and stop a supply line into Laverty and the OrsquoHagens, McConvilles and Carrs are in for a busy night of it..prettyPhoto

title: Sisters hosting night of music with Community Gospel Choir
story: THE countdown is on to this Saturday eveningrsquos fundraising concert in Downpatrick in aid of Cancer Focus NI.Sisters Emma and Evie Telford are busy with the final preparations for the event in memory of their mum Lorna who passed away just over five years ago.The concert mdash which is being held at the Quoile Bar and Bistro at the Strangford Road in the town mdash starts at .pm.Emma and Evie have organised a number of fundraising events in memory of their mum to support Cancer Focus NI, a charity which was of great comfort and help to them in the run-up to their mumrsquos passing and after her death.A non-smoker, Mrs Telford died on September , , following a long battle with lung cancer.The Downpatrick sisters are keen to give something back to a charity which helped them, with the money they raise being used to support the Cancer Focus Family Support Service.Emma and Evie want to help other children and young people who will have to deal with the devastating news that their mum or dad is terminally ill.ldquoWe want to raise money for Cancer Focus because the charity means so much to us. There are lots of cancer organisations who all do a wonderful job but, in a way, Cancer Focus inextricably links us to our mum, said the girls.ldquoRachel Smith from the charityrsquos family support service worked closely with mum, dad and us. She played a big part in our lives at what was a devastating and particularly challenging time.ldquoWe miss mum so much, but she has left us with so many memories.ldquoMum will always be with us and we want to raise money to help families who find themselves in the situation we did. Mum was diagnosed in June  and she fought a brave battle. She never complained and her one focus throughout her illness was us dad and us.The sisters described their mum as the ldquorock at the heart of the family and explained that they have been inspired by how she dealt with her terminal illness.ldquoCancer Focus is a great charity. Its staff work at the coalface with families who have been plunged into crisis. The staff are there to listen, help and advise at what is undoubtedly the most challenging time in anyonersquos le, Emma and Evie continued.ldquoRachel Smith became part of not just our family, but all those she works with. Words simply cannot describe what she does. When you are in the depth of despair she is there for you, knowing exactly what to do and say.Looking ahead to Saturdayrsquos concert, the sisters said the one word that springs to mind is ldquouplting.Emma, who is a member of the Community Gospel Choir, said its performances are not strictly gospel, with a number of modern and classic songs part of the repertoire.ldquoEveryone who leaves our concerts says they always feel uplted. For those who have never heard the choir before, they are in for a treat on Saturday night, she added.Evie said the fundraisers she and her sister organise are about keeping their mumrsquos memory alive as well as supporting Cancer Focus NI.ldquoWe are glad that we can help other families who may be in the same situation as we were via our fundraising. We really are so thankful for all the support that we received from Cancer Focus and hope people have a great time on Saturday evening, she said.ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council is supporting the concert and we also want to thank all the businesses who have supported our fundraising concert programme which is free and will be handed out on the night. Thanks to all those who donated raffle prizes and to the Quoile Bar and Bistro for hosting the concert. It will be a great night.Tickets priced pound. for Saturdayrsquos concert are available at Down Recorder reception or from Davidor Emma Telford . A limited number of tickets will be available to purchase on the night as will a number of childrenrsquos tickets priced pound.Tickets are also available on line via the Cancer Focus website or contact charity representative Barbara Long, telephone , email barbaralong@cancerfocusni.org..prettyPhoto

title: Vandals wreck picnic tables at beauty spot
story: A PICNIC table that was completely smashed at a local beauty spot has been condemned as ldquoindiscriminate petty vandalism by a local councillor.One of two wooden picnic tables located at the edge of Spa Lake was recently ripped from the ground and thrown down an embankment close to the edge of the lake.Slieve Croob councillor, Alan Lewis, said he was ldquodisgusted to learn of the recent vandalism and the burden it will now place on the local council and ratepayers to replace.He is also urging the local authority to replace the bench as soon as possible for people visiting the area and local fishermen who often frequent the local lake.Cllr Lewis continued: ldquoThis is simply unacceptable and I was disappointed to learn of this recent vandalism from residents who advised me what had happened. I could not believe someone had dislodged the picnic table, smashed it to bits and threw it over the bank down towards the lake.Cllr Lewis, who visited the area recently to review the damage, says the table has also been thrown in an awkward place for council staff to retrieve.ldquoThe council has neither the time nor the resources to continually waste on repairing this type ofdamage. Are those responsible bored  he said. ldquoIrsquom at a loss as to what type of iniduals would do this.Cllr Lewis said he is also open to the idea of meeting with those responsible in order to direct their frustrations where.He added: ldquoIf there is some type of recreational activity that you would like funded, then make contact with me, letrsquos have a chat, but blatant indiscriminate petty vandalism must stop immediately. It is disheartening and disappointing to see this type of behaviour which is senseless, idiotic vandalism..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health.
